awd_titl_txt: Planning Grant: Engineering Research Center for Digital Twins in Engineering and Medicine
awd_abstract_narration:
Decisions are made every day about medical procedures such as surgeries or drug treatments: they affect and condition the future of patients. They are based on established best practices, but do not necessarily account for the individual traits of a person. A similar decision-making process can be found in complex engineering systems, or the maintenance schedule of an aircraft. During the last decade however,it has been recognized that the transition to personalized medicine will potentially enhance the life of patients and increase the quality of clinical care, as well as potentially lower the overall healthcare costs. A similar observation has been made regarding complex engineering systems, with a call to develop cyber-physical systems and dynamic data processes that use massive amounts of data to drive individual smart machines. The practical realization of this transition requires 1) the development of a new technology for extracting meaningful information from data and interpreting it correctly, 2) an accompanying plan for educating the future workforce in this global area, and 3) the identification and resolution of the associated ethical and privacy issues. This planning grant will develop the vision for the proposed Center to influence this transformation during the next two decades by influencing the health monitoring and decision-making processes of living and non-living physical entities in these important areas using digital twins. These are digital replicas of living and non-living physical entities. Their underlying concept integrates artificial intelligence, machine learning, and software analytics with physics-based modeling. Their main purpose is to act as living digital simulation models that are continuously trained and updated to be able to mirror the states and behaviors of their physical counterparts.

This grant will focus on planning the development of a Center that will integrate research groups working on core technologies for digital twins, such as algorithms, hardware, software,physics-based machine learning, and mathematics and statistics, with counterparts working on three significantly different application areas: aircraft health monitoring; customized weight loss programs; and qualification of metal 3D printed parts. This integration will define the common requirements for digital twins, advance these application areas and explore their societal and ethical implications. This will establish a multi-disciplinary dialog between mathematicians, engineers, medical doctors, lawyers and philosophers, and a convergent vision for how to shape the future of this technology. The grant will enable an Exploratory Workshop that will serve to identify the broad stakeholder community in academia and the corporate world and government, form the team and management structure, and most importantly, define a multi-disciplinary, convergent vision for a future Engineering Research Center in Digital Twins for Engineering and Medicine. The dialog that this planning grant will foster on the subjects of digital twins, engineering workforce development, diversity and culture of inclusion, and innovation ecosystem will build new connections between a diverse group of researchers and practitioners from different institutions and disciplines and identify the potential members of the Center. Additionally, explicit efforts are planned to engage partners from institutions that serve primarily underrepresented minorities in the activities of this planning grant. The impact of the newly formed connections with a shared interest in digital twins, in line with the idea of fostering a convergent research, has the potential to spring other areas of collaboration in the future.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

por.por_cntn:
During the last decade, it has been recognized that the transition to precision medicine will “enhance the life of patients and increase the quality of clinical care,” as well as “lower overall healthcare costs’’. Similarly, a call has been made to develop cyber-physical systems that exploit massive amounts of data to drive smartly engineered individual machines. Realizing this transformation across multiple disciplines is a grand challenge problem whose solution is beyond any Multidisciplinary University Research Initiative (MURI)-like effort and certainly beyond any individual research effort. It requires developing new technology for extracting fundamental information from data and exploiting it to drive innovation. It also requires an accompanying plan for educating the future diverse workforce in this area. Hence, realizing the aforementioned transformation requires a Convergent Engineering Research Center (CERC). Under this funded research effort, Stanford University, the University of California at Santa Barbara, the University of California at San Francisco, Brown University, the University of Central Florida, and the University of Texas at El Paso developed and submitted to NSF a preproposal for a CERC on Digital Twins in Engineering and Medicine (DTEM). The preproposal offered to build on the current exploratory steps led by the engineering, manufacturing, automotive, and energy industries to enable the aforementioned transformation during the next two decades. In the context of the Fourth Industrial Revolution characterized by a fusion of technologies that is blurring the lines between the physical, digital and biological spheres, DTEM was to address a grand challenge problem whose solution would have offered enormous benefits to society.  

Specifically, DTEM’s vision was grounded in a transdisciplinary research and workforce development effort for creating new value in the health monitoring of living and non-living physical entities, product maintenance and support, disaster risk monitoring and early-warning, and decision-making processes using Digital Twins (DTs). Here, a DT is a digital replica of a living or non-living as-built system such as a physical asset, or as-practiced process such as the manufacturing or certification of this asset. It is based on the best available multiphysics, multiscale, probabilistic computational models, sensor information and input data, to mirror if possible and predict the activities and performance over the life cycle of its corresponding physical twin.  

DTEM’s primary objectives were to provide manufacturers and health professionals a live window inside a system at all times; enable the effective support of physical assets via a predictive rather than preventive maintenance; and stimulate innovation by delivering faster insights into systems to drive opportunities for transformation and growth. Fundamentally, the new compelling ideas that emerged from this effort and became the scientific pillars of the preproposal were: 1) How to extract knowledge from different types of data not captured by today’s best computational models; 2) How to infuse it in such models to boost their predictive capabilities; and 3) How to perform this rapidly to enable coupling a DT with its physical counterpart to assess its past, current and future states. These were and remain high-risk/high-payoff ideas. DTEM would have developed them to integrate fundamental data sciences and computational engineering research with technological innovation. Existing barriers to DT development would have been overcome by DTEM’s transdisciplinary approach, where successful engineering-specific approaches such as physics-based modeling, approaches prevailing in medicine such as knowledge networks, and computer-science-specific approaches such as deep learning would have cross-fertilized to generate fundamentally new conceptual modeling frameworks that transcend their disciplinary origins and catalyze innovation.  

To drive the collective research agenda, DTEM was to develop four DT testbeds for four different applications: 1) Aircraft crisis management and predictive maintenance, for its potential impact on travel safety and the economy; 2) Rapid qualification of metal additively manufactured parts, for its potential impact on energy requirements for transportation systems and national security; 3) Personalized cardiovascular surgical planning, for its potential to cause a paradigm shift in routine clinical practice and benefits to health; and 4) The prediction of outcomes for preterm babies, for its potential impact on survival and benefits to long-term health. To this end, DTEM would have integrated diverse research groups working on core technologies for DTs such as physics-based and data-driven surrogate modeling, knowledge networks, machine learning, mathematics and statistics, with counterparts working on the aforementioned applications in engineering and medicine. This would have established a transdisciplinary dialogue between engineers, doctors, biologists, computer scientists, mathematicians and statisticians, and led to a convergent vision for how to shape the future of DT technology. It would also have led to the identification of common requirements for DTs, the solution of the associated technical challenges, the advancement of their applications and the exploration of their societal implications. In turn, this would have maximized the potential for the impact of DT technology on society, the engineering community and the greater scientific community. Unfortunately, the preproposal for DTEM was not successful.


Last Modified: 12/19/2021
Modified by: Charbel Farhat
por.por_txt_cntn:
During the last decade, it has been recognized that the transition to precision medicine will "enhance the life of patients and increase the quality of clinical  care," as well as "lower overall healthcare costs’’. Similarly, a call  has been made to develop cyber-physical systems that exploit massive  amounts of data to drive smartly engineered individual machines.  Realizing this transformation across multiple disciplines is a grand  challenge problem whose solution is beyond any Multidisciplinary  University Research Initiative (MURI)-like effort and certainly beyond  any individual research effort. It requires developing new technology  for extracting fundamental information from data and exploiting it to drive innovation. It also requires an accompanying plan for educating the future diverse workforce in this area. Hence, realizing the aforementioned  transformation requires a Convergent Engineering Research Center (CERC).  Under this funded research effort, Stanford University, the University  of California at Santa Barbara, the University of California at San  Francisco, Brown University, the University of Central Florida, and the  University of Texas at El Paso developed and submitted to NSF a  preproposal for a CERC on Digital Twins in Engineering and Medicine  (DTEM). The preproposal offered to build on the current exploratory  steps led by the engineering, manufacturing, automotive, and energy  industries to enable the aforementioned transformation during the next  two decades. In the context of the Fourth Industrial Revolution  characterized by a fusion of technologies that is blurring the lines  between the physical, digital and biological spheres, DTEM was to  address a grand challenge problem whose solution would have offered  enormous benefits to society.  

Specifically,  DTEM’s vision was grounded in a transdisciplinary research and  workforce development effort for creating new value in the health  monitoring of living and non-living physical entities, product  maintenance and support, disaster risk monitoring and early-warning, and  decision-making processes using Digital Twins (DTs). Here, a DT is a digital replica of a living or non-living as-built system such as a physical asset, or as-practiced process such as the manufacturing or certification of this asset. It is  based on the best available multiphysics, multiscale, probabilistic  computational models, sensor information and input data, to mirror if  possible and predict the activities and performance over the life cycle  of its corresponding physical twin.  

DTEM’s  primary objectives were to provide manufacturers and health  professionals a live window inside a system at all times; enable the  effective support of physical assets via a predictive rather than  preventive maintenance; and stimulate innovation by delivering faster  insights into systems to drive opportunities for transformation and  growth. Fundamentally, the new compelling ideas that emerged from this  effort and became the scientific pillars of the preproposal were: 1) How  to extract knowledge from different types of data not captured by  today’s best computational models; 2) How to infuse it in such models to  boost their predictive capabilities; and 3) How to perform this rapidly  to enable coupling a DT with its physical counterpart to assess its  past, current and future states. These were and remain  high-risk/high-payoff ideas. DTEM would have developed them to integrate  fundamental data sciences and computational engineering research with  technological innovation. Existing barriers to DT development would have  been overcome by DTEM’s transdisciplinary approach, where successful  engineering-specific approaches such as physics-based modeling,  approaches prevailing in medicine such as knowledge networks, and  computer-science-specific approaches such  as deep learning would have cross-fertilized to generate fundamentally  new conceptual modeling frameworks that transcend their disciplinary  origins and catalyze innovation.  

To  drive the collective research agenda, DTEM was to develop four DT  testbeds for four different applications: 1) Aircraft crisis management  and predictive maintenance, for its potential impact on travel safety  and the economy; 2) Rapid qualification of metal additively manufactured  parts, for its potential impact on energy requirements for  transportation systems and national security; 3) Personalized  cardiovascular surgical planning, for its potential to cause a paradigm shift in routine clinical practice and benefits  to health; and 4) The prediction of outcomes for preterm babies, for  its potential impact on survival and benefits to long-term health. To  this end, DTEM would have integrated diverse research  groups working on core technologies for DTs such as physics-based and  data-driven surrogate modeling, knowledge networks, machine learning,  mathematics and statistics, with counterparts working on the  aforementioned applications in engineering and medicine. This would have  established a transdisciplinary dialogue between engineers, doctors,  biologists, computer scientists, mathematicians and statisticians, and  led to a convergent vision for how to shape the future of DT technology.  It would also have led to the identification of common requirements for  DTs, the solution of the associated technical challenges, the  advancement of their applications and the exploration of their societal  implications. In turn, this would have maximized the potential for the  impact of DT technology on society, the engineering community and the  greater scientific community. Unfortunately, the preproposal for DTEM was not successful.
